Inman.Action: Gets up and continues to play fiercely despite injury, showing resilience and commitment to his team.
Watches Ada with astonishment and gentle attention, indicating a soft and sincere interest.
Recovers quickly after being hit, gets up despite bleeding from his nose, and continues to charge in the game.
Is momentarily distracted by Ada's arrival during the game, looking astonished.
Watches Ada carefully across the crowd while enduring pain from a cheek wound, showing quiet attentiveness.
Engages in casual conversation with Swimmer about the Cherokee curse and war prospects, showing friendliness and openness.
Keeps distance from the new arrivals initially, observing rather than interacting directly.
Allows Swimmer to sew a gash in his cheek while staying still despite pain.
Observes surroundings carefully as others interact and arrives focused on Ada.
Doubts the duration of the war without strong evidence, showing some naivety.
Loading his heavy LeMats pistol carefully and staying alert in the Confederate lines before dawn.
Not showing signs of distraction or weakness, focused on preparing before potential conflict.
Looks over amused at Rourke’s playfulness with the rabbit but goes back to his gun, showing a quiet, reserved demeanor.
Observes the explosion calmly, shows amusement at the rabbit chase, then returns to his post without distraction.
Disappears under dirt and debris in the explosion, no mention of immediate action to protect himself or others.
Rushes through the smoke to the pit and fights fiercely alongside comrades, fighting to protect and survive together.
Engages in brutal hand-to-hand combat, acting as a coldly efficient killer in a desperate battle.
Stands appalled and exhausted after battle, yells at wounded soldier attempting to drag himself away from danger, showing concern.
Turns away disgusted from a soldier who is brutally smashing the skulls of wounded enemies, implying refusal to condone cruelty.
Stands exhausted and appalled after fierce combat, witnessing atrocities and chaos without losing composure.
Yells at a wounded Federal soldier trying to escape, indicating situational awareness and command presence.
Passively observes brutal acts (skull smashing, mutilation) and turns away without intervening.
Glares at Stobrod but allows him to play the fiddle despite initial hesitation.
Abruptly stops Stobrod's emotionally wrenching fiddle playing and walks away after being reminded of a dead boy.
Reads a book carefully and keeps a faded tintype photograph of a solemn young woman close by, showing sentimental attachment.
Makes a stand firmly and respectfully when approached by an officer, expressing concern about his transfer and medical corps volunteering.
Immediately stands up and fires to protect his group when discovered by the enemy, killing several foes.
Stops to turn back and carry wounded comrade Butcher, despite dangerous circumstances.
Immediately stands and fires killing three enemies as they awaken, showing quick reaction and combat skill.
Works with his men to silently approach enemy, showing tactical awareness and stealth.
Stops and runs back to carry wounded Butcher, risking his own safety to save a comrade.
Gets caught in an enemy flare and is shot, indicating possible miscalculation or bad luck but no clear incompetence.
Works alongside others building a chapel, hammering nails and participating in communal labor.
Immediately looks away when pointed at as someone pressing Sally, showing some social discomfort or avoidance.
Observes Ada thoughtfully, indicating awareness of social dynamics.
Politely accepts lemonade from Ada and says thank you despite discomfort and provocation from other men.
Acknowledges others staring and the hostile atmosphere but does not react with aggression; keeps to himself.
Responds to Ada's questions straightforwardly but with minimal small talk; appears guarded and somewhat distant.
Dismisses the idea of calling others friends and scowls at men jostling him, showing mistrust and detachment.
Responds to Ada's questions calmly and directly, maintains composure despite being stared at and jostled by others.
Shrugs off forced repetition of his name and keeps interaction straightforward, showing social awareness and confidence.
Avoids conflict by giving a polite 'thank you' and returning to join the others rather than escalating tension.
Is visibly uncomfortable when asked about clearing fields, indicates some hesitation or lack of confidence in certain skills.
Keeps his head fixed on the table while others tease him, showing endurance without retaliating.
Clears his debt to Sally quietly and without complaint, indicating responsibility and sincerity.
Keeps his head fixed on the table despite teasing, showing composure.
Wounded and unconscious on a gurney, unable to act or influence events.
Smiles and waves back at Ada as she plays piano and nods to the farmhand, showing friendly acknowledgment.
Stands outside in the rain, watching and listening quietly to the celebration inside instead of joining in.
Works hard in the field under hot conditions, wielding a scythe skillfully.
Observes the social situation at the Chapel celebration quietly from outside, showing patience and restraint.
Takes the tray from Ada to deliver drinks to others despite being wet and uncomfortable.
Responds bluntly and briefly to Ada's questions, avoiding engagement and showing emotional reserve.
Offers family sheet music to Ada and Monroe, indicating a gesture of sharing and connection.
Takes the tray from Ada to deliver drinks to the negroes in the barn himself despite being wet and uncomfortable.
Responds to Ada's questions about enlisting with guarded, somewhat indirect answers, showing self-control and thoughtfulness.
Hovers awkwardly outside the farmhouse, showing social discomfort or uncertainty.
Offers his father's sheet music to Ada, acknowledging it is of no use to him, demonstrating practical judgment.
Agrees to take a walk with Ada and Monroe, showing openness to their company.
Acknowledges the beauty of the land modestly ('I think so') when complimented by Monroe.
Looks at Ada silently instead of speaking when offered a ride back into town.
Decides to leave the gathering politely and without fuss, indicating self-awareness and confidence in his preferences.
Looks at Ada without responding when offered a ride back into town, showing restraint and possibly good judgment about his next action.
Fixes on Ada with quiet attention and remains when others leave the church.
Steps between Esco and Teague calmly, holding Teague's horse reins to challenge his authority.
Steps between Esco and Teague, holding the reins of Teague's horse, displaying calm control in a potentially violent confrontation.
Remains fixated on Ada during the church singing, ignoring the spreading news and wider situation.
Acknowledges Ada might be safer elsewhere but subtly invites her to follow him inside the chapel, indicating concern and hope for connection.
Seeks a quiet moment with Ada despite the noisy, chaotic environment, showing a desire for sincere, private communication.
Sits alone in a sparse, bare room, packing and preparing to leave, showing emotional restraint but no hostility or coldness.
Makes clear and intentional gestures to communicate meaning nonverbally, inviting Ada to follow him inside the chapel.
Takes a quiet moment alone sitting on a bench to presumably think or plan amidst the chaotic environment.
Sits in a nearly empty, ascetic room quietly polishing his boots, preparing for travel with careful attention.
Shows hesitation or difficulty in verbalizing feelings or declarations with Ada despite their mutual desire to do so.
Abruptly closes the door on Ada.
Accepts gifts from Ada and kisses her sincerely.
Looks back to see Ada as he marches away, showing concern and connection.
Abruptly closes the door on Ada when she arrives unexpectedly.
Takes the book Ada gives him and interacts tenderly and awkwardly with her, showing emotional intelligence and sensitivity.
Kisses Ada gently and holds her waist, expressing affection confidently.
Pulls away promptly when the recruitment parade arrives and joins the marching volunteers quickly.
Looks back briefly at Ada but quickly loses sight of her in the crowd, implying focus on immediate task rather than distraction.
Struggles with injury and pain but resists despair, asserting 'I'm not dying.'
Maintains focus and asserts 'I'm not dying' despite severe injury and near-unconsciousness.
Unable to push away the fiddle or significantly control his environment due to weakened state.
Murmurs names of loved ones faintly while gravely ill, connecting to personal memories despite his suffering.
Does not respond to Mrs. Morgan's concern with clear words, causing some confusion.
Murmurs names of loved ones and places while delirious and near death, showing mental presence despite severe condition.
Despite weakness and unconsciousness, shows determination with a tiny nod when hearing Ada's request to come back.
Inman remains very still and weak, possibly showing physical incapacity or fragility at this moment.
Considers the picture of Ada, showing connection and care.
Sits quietly among fellow wounded soldiers, appearing still and sick.
Dips bandage in seawater and tends wound patiently.
Carefully tends to his wound by dipping his bandage in seawater and applying it thoughtfully.
Sits still and appears weak and sick in the hospital wheelchair, showing limited active engagement.
Approaches hospital gate despite being frail and at risk of capture, interacts calmly with guard and blind man.
Speaks in a croaking voice and walks with an unsteady, lurching gait indicating physical weakness.
Quietly leaves the hospital at dawn, prepared and determined to move forward.
Cleans his wound and prepares to escape the hospital by carefully shaving despite the risk and walks out the window fully dressed and ready.
No direct action or statement in this excerpt; indirect context only.
No direct action or involvement in the scene is shown; Ruby handles labor and threats decisively, while Ada looks intimidated.
Looks at the group of slaves on the run and offers to pay for food, showing a gentle and sincere attempt to connect and help despite his own hardship.
Pays no heed to the escaping slaves and they pay no heed to him, showing a certain distance and lack of engagement with others in distress.
Hears riders approaching, quickly hides by lying low in the tall cornfield, showing situational awareness and caution.
Does not engage or interfere with the group of slaves and prisoners wandering nearby, choosing instead to avoid unnecessary confrontation.
Attempts to trade with the group by offering money for food, showing resourcefulness and confidence in social interaction despite the risk.
The group ignores his offer, indicating limited success or influence in the situation, but he does not escalate or react impulsively.
Stops and carefully observes the distant flickering light, listening intently to assess the situation.
Approaches a man struggling to carry the body of a black girl, showing concern and attention to a dire situation.
Walks a dangerous, precarious rocky track at night, alert and focused, listens carefully, pulls out weapon in anticipation of confrontation.
Points a gun at Veasey to prevent him from throwing the girl down the gorge, commands him to reverse his dangerous action.
Engages Veasey in dialogue to understand the situation and gain information about the girl and Veasey’s intentions.
Shows emotional vulnerability (tear-stained face) while handling the girl and situation.
Leads the horse with Veasey tied up, indicating control over the dangerous man and circumstance.
Shuts Veasey down firmly to stop his sermonizing.
Insists Veasey return the girl to where she sleeps despite risk.
Keeps gun trained on Veasey but allows him to care for the girl.
Is incredulous at Veasey's selfishness about waking his wife, showing concern for the girl's safety.
Pins a written note on a distressed Veasey tied to a tree, holding him accountable in a public and possibly humiliating way.
Insists Veasey put the girl back where she sleeps and intervenes to prevent Veasey's wrongdoing.
Keeps Veasey under control by tying him to a tree and posting a handwritten note as a form of public shaming.
Pulls a handkerchief from Veasey's jacket and stuffs it into his mouth, cutting Veasey's angry speech short, then walks away leaving Veasey tied to a tree, cursing.
Silences Veasey by stuffing a handkerchief in his mouth, then calmly walks away leaving him tied to a tree.
Negotiates the ferry price assertively and offers more money to secure passage.
Immediately rejects Veasey's attempt to join him despite the risk, showing decisiveness.
Expresses frustration and anger towards Veasey but quickly chooses practical action by escaping in the canoe.
After being rescued from drowning by Veasey, despite their hostile history, Inman verbally acknowledges their antagonism but does not retaliate physically or vengefully.
Engages in a bitter exchange with Veasey, reflecting mutual animosity and lack of friendliness.
Rocks the canoe to turn it over, enabling escape from sniper fire despite being injured
Sinks after being hit on the head by the canoe, needing Veasey to haul him to the surface
Holds on despite being underwater multiple times and wounded, showing endurance and presence of mind
Appears vulnerable and physically incapacitated after being dragged ashore and kicked by Veasey
Silences Veasey suddenly to avoid detection by riders, showing concern for their safety.
Objects to Veasey taking the found saw, appealing to morality about stealing.
Walks away vexed when Veasey continues to consider taking the saw.
Carefully scouts the track and edges towards the river bank with great caution.
Refuses liquor, showing self-control and focus.
Questions Veasey about the plan, showing engagement and willingness to understand before acting.
Takes charge of the saw and organizes Junior to work effectively, indicating leadership and practical skill.
Does not question Veasey's authority or expertise but participates actively, showing social intelligence and adaptability.
States he doesn't know where Veasey is heading and is focused on his own journey, indicating self-awareness and decisiveness.
Directs the sawing of the bull's neck in chapters, showing organized approach.
Advises to leave off water from the carcass for a day or two to avoid tangy taste.
Explains to Junior that Veasey is excusing himself to defecate, showing practical understanding of situation.
Responds matter-of-factly to Junior's questions without judgment or mockery.
Allows Shyla to help him with bathing, showing trust and accepting kindness.
Keeps personal belongings and maintains modesty by turning his back to the door when bathing.
Does not engage with the women’s sexual appraisal and remains reserved.
Stows his knapsack securely and prepares to wash in the tub, demonstrating purposeful and practical behavior.
Explains simply and clearly to Junior about the preacher being a Christian, showing clear communication.
Thanks Shyla when she compliments or acknowledges him despite feeling uncomfortable with her stare.
Becomes drunk and detached, showing a glazed look, not fully engaging with the others respectfully.
Gets increasingly drunk, eyes glazed, behaves vaguely and unresponsive.
Offers Junior his house, implying a welcoming attitude.
Suddenly gets up and sways, then lies down as if unwell, showing vulnerability.
Suddenly gets up and sways, then stumbles and curls up by the fire due to head spinning.
Surrenders passively to Lila's advances while drunk, shows no resistance to her.
Does not retaliate or resist when violently attacked by Junior, remains passive.
Is drunk, unresponsive, allowing himself to be manipulated and surprised by an armed enemy.
Tries to pull up the older man who collapsed and points out he is dead, showing concern for others.
Shouts to the Home Guard leader about the dead man and tries to make others pay attention, but is ignored.
Tells Sheffield that if he runs, they all run together, including the lame and stupid.
Asks for warning so he can avoid being shot for a cause he doesn't believe in.
Calmly assesses Sheffield's suggestion and responds pragmatically, indicating a clear-headed approach.
States he will warn the guard before attempting escape, showing cautious planning and self-preservation.
Shouts 'No!' in alarm when prisoners put themselves in danger crossing the train tracks.
Turns away from Veasey, focusing elsewhere during a tense moment.
Realizes the danger of the oncoming train and yells a warning 'No!'
Unable to prevent Sheffield from pulling the prisoners into the path of the train nonetheless
Uses all his strength to catch and lift Veasey, preventing him from falling fatally down the bank.
Suffers a head wound but continues amidst chaos without indication of self-pity or withdrawal.
Uses all his strength to catch the falling prisoner Veasey and lifts him, showing physical capability and quick reaction.
Sustains a head wound and continues despite bleeding profusely, indicating resilience but possibly impaired effectiveness.
Feels a surprising loss and tenderness upon seeing Veasey's corpse, indicating emotional sensitivity and capacity for connection even in dire circumstances.
Focuses on survival and distracts the goat by rattling chains, showing practical but not particularly warm behavior.
Regains consciousness buried under dead bodies and chained limbs, manages to distract a goat and free himself despite pain and difficulty breathing.
Inman is inching along the embankment, dragging a chain of dead bodies, remaining aware of his surroundings as he notices the goats and prepares to react.
Inman suddenly finds himself staring down the barrel of a shotgun, indicating a potentially dangerous and compromising situation.
Allows Maddy to care for him despite groaning and trying to defend himself.
Responds to Maddy's concern with brief, honest answers about his wounds.
Tries to sit up despite severe injury, groans and attempts to defend himself even while barely conscious.
Expresses concern for Maddy's safety if he is found at her place.
Emerges pale and unsteady, showing vulnerability and implicit trust in Maddy by allowing himself to be cared for.
Emerges from the caravan pale and unsteady, aware of his vulnerable state and the risks of being found as a deserter.
Expresses urgency and determination to not stay longer than necessary, showing awareness of consequences.
Shows confusion about time and place initially, indicating some disorientation.
Nods in thanks to Maddy for adding more meat to his plate, but doesn't look up.
Swallows the lozenge despite suspicion and gagging at the taste.
Admits feeling crazy and hungry, speaks honestly about his past and feelings for Ada.
Surrenders to Maddy's care and follows her instructions to heal his wounds.
Expresses a philosophical and resigned acceptance of life and death.
Reflects deeply and emotionally on places near home, showing vulnerability and connection to homeland and loved ones.
Reflects deeply on places and names, showing emotional vulnerability but also thoughtful introspection.
No direct actions or statements present in the excerpt to assess warmth.
No direct actions or statements from Inman in this excerpt to assess competence.
Thanks Maddy sincerely for her help and acknowledges his debt to her.
Kills Junior by surprise, showing a readiness to kill an opponent.
Takes a flintlock pistol despite being told it's mostly for show, indicating preparedness.
Successfully ambushes Junior by perching silently in a tree and shooting him.
Drags Junior's corpse in and retrieves his bag with weapons and personal items, maintaining composure and focus.
Walks away from the women mourning the corpse without looking at them.
Trudges wearily through harsh winter landscape, tending carefully to his wounds and rationing his food and drink.
Walks away from women keening over a corpse without engagement or offering help.
Continues traveling despite physical frailty and pain from leg irons, managing to eat and tend to his wounds.
Uncertain about which path to take, chooses direction based on a crow's call rather than clear knowledge or strategy.
Seeks shelter from a woman in the rain, clearly stating he has no bad intention and only needs food and shelter.
Accepts woman's refusal to let him in without argument and prepares to leave respectfully.
Carefully assesses the risk of approaching Sara's cabin in bad weather.
Politely and clearly states his need and intentions when knocking on the door.
Accepts the initial refusal to enter without argument and offered an alternative shelter.
Offers gun handle-first to Sara to show he means no harm, demonstrating careful consideration and intention to build trust.
Shows restraint and respect by turning his back when Sara needs privacy to feed her baby.
Despite hunger, bites into an onion and eats humble food, showing adaptability and acceptance of harsh conditions.
Appears mesmerized and somewhat passive, not leading the conversation or situation actively.
Offers to help Sara with butchering the hog despite her refusal.
Introduces himself sincerely and expresses gladness to know Sara and her baby.
Follows Sara carrying steaming water and a towel, showing attentiveness and care.
Shares his blanket with Sara when she admits she has none.
Peels off clothes and scrubs clean in view, then modestly turns away to pull off pants.
Offers to help Sara by doing the difficult task of butchering the hog, showing willingness and skill.
Brings a bowl of steaming water and towel to Sara, showing preparedness and attentiveness.
Offers his blanket when Sara mentions she doesn't have one, demonstrating resourcefulness and care.
Peels off clothes and cleans himself carefully, turning away modestly when seen, showing self-awareness but not affecting competence positively or negatively.
Reluctantly settles outside in the cold rather than impose on Sara, despite longing for warmth and companionship.
Responds to Sara’s invitation inside with openness and tenderness, attempting to stay close but respecting emotional boundaries.
Comforts Sara as she sobs, allowing her to fold into him, showing sensitivity and care.
Selects and acknowledges good boots, indicating practical judgement in gear.
Settles down to rest in uncomfortable conditions but remains alert, reaching for weapons upon hearing noise.
Responds honestly and cautiously to Sara's request about intimacy ('I don't know. I'll try.'), showing emotional awareness and self-control.
Allows himself to be vulnerable and supportive when Sara cries, showing emotional competence which supports his overall capability.
Wakes abruptly when warned by Sara, quickly prepares to leave to avoid trouble for her and the baby.
Offers to fight the Federal soldiers despite risk to himself, showing protective instinct.
Heeds Sara's plea to leave rather than fight, respecting her wishes and prioritizing safety.
Observes Sara and baby being harmed without intervening, restrained by circumstances but forced passivity.
Surfaces from deep sleep quickly when warned and prepares to leave immediately.
Grabs his gun and suggests fighting the approaching Federals.
Does not engage the soldiers directly when they raid the cabin; instead retreats to avoid confrontation and preserve himself.
Throws clothes out the window and escapes by swinging out and running underdressed in freezing conditions to avoid detection.
Watches helplessly as Sara is tied up and the baby is taken outside without intervening.
Clubs down Pistol to protect Sara and her baby, kills Nym who was abusing Sara.
Instructs Bardolph to move away from the baby, indicating concern for the child's safety.
Clubs down Pistol unexpectedly and kills Nym to defend Sara and her baby.
Confronts Bardolph while armed and confident, commanding him to move away from the baby.
Commands Bardolph to disarm and leave, demonstrating control and authority in a tense situation.
Shoots Bardolph after securing compliance, decisively removing a threat.
Butchers the hog efficiently, performing complex survival tasks with skill and focus.
Continues work silently despite emotional tension, showing ability to maintain composure under stress.
Glances back anxiously at Sara and the baby but does not intervene, showing emotional conflict and a limit in his capability to act beyond survival tasks in the moment.
Allows Sara to serve him food and accepts her gentle touch without rejection.
Does not look at Sara when she approaches him, showing emotional distance.
Controls his grief rigidly at the sight of two dead bodies to avoid being overwhelmed.
Digs a grave for the dead, showing respect and responsibility.
Eats quietly and accepts food without complaint, indicating calm composure under stress.
Responds to the revolver shot with slow, deliberate approach to the scene of two dead bodies, showing controlled awareness and emotional restraint.
Works outside in fading light and snow to dig a grave for the dead, demonstrating practical skill and a sense of responsibility.
Does not look at the woman who serves him, possibly indicating emotional detachment or discomfort, which may suggest difficulty in interpersonal situational awareness.
Slides down a crumbling slate hill but recovers and continues on towards his destination after spotting the Blue Ridge
Observes the geography and keeps focus on home and Ada, showing clear goal orientation
No direct action or statement present in this excerpt; no display of skill or decision-making.
Studies the ground carefully, showing respect to the dead by finding Pangle's grave and tracking footprints quietly.
Touches the cold ashes of Ruby's fire, unable to find warmth, silently experiencing the cold and desolation around him.
Shudders at the cold stream water, showing sensitivity to his surroundings and physical vulnerability.
Moves quickly to preserve the tracks in the snow, racing to maintain evidence of the journey and those involved.
Studies the ground thoroughly, follows subtle tracks and signs including blood spatters and prints to continue his pursuit.
Uses knowledge of environment (fire ashes, blood, tracks, snow) to gauge situation and pursue at dawn with urgency.
Moves quickly to race snow covering tracks, demonstrating awareness of time-sensitive tracking conditions.
Runs toward the Chestnut trees upon hearing gunshots, showing alertness and situational awareness.
Initially fails to recognize Ada in men's clothes and does not immediately identify her voice.
After realizing the mistake, he turns to leave but then turns again, appearing lost and without clear direction.
Eventually acknowledges Ada, accepts her invitation, and moves forward with the situation despite emotional difficulty.
Nods to Ruby when asked if he's hungry, silently accepting care.
Quietly sleeps on the floor, showing vulnerability and trust.
Responds minimally about needing sleep and not shooting lately, somewhat reserved but sincere.
Nods when asked if he's hungry, quietly accepts help and rest, shows awareness of his condition (he looks played out)
Responds with short, minimal answers (e.g., 'I may need to', 'Not lately'), indicating physical or mental exhaustion.
Expresses regret for disturbing Ada, shows vulnerability by admitting no appetite around wounded men.
Shares intimate feelings and memories with Ada, revealing his deep emotional connection and sincerity.
Prays for Ada's wellbeing and confesses she keeps him from descending into darkness.
Communicates thoughtfully and meaningfully with Ada, showing emotional insight and clarity.
Admits to having no appetite to be around wounded men, signaling emotional vulnerability but also situational awareness.
Expresses feelings poetically and with deep reflection, indicating emotional intelligence and self-awareness.
Relies heavily on memories and emotions which may be subjective and partially imagined, suggesting possible emotional bias rather than practicality.
Expresses fear of having lost his goodness and tenderness, revealing vulnerability and self-awareness.
States he 'shot' any tenderness dead in himself, suggesting emotional suppression and self-judgment.
Responds politely and respectfully when entering Ada's hut, observing social boundaries.
Agrees with Ada that Ruby should stay as long as she wants, showing tolerance and respect for others.
Expresses deep emotional vulnerability and self-doubt about his inner self and spirit
Demonstrates respectful restraint by saying goodnight and not intruding further
Agrees to Ada's wish regarding Ruby staying in Black Cove without resistance
Expresses desire to marry Ada sincerely, saying 'I want to marry you. If you'll have me.'
Responds kindly and supportively to Ada's insecurities about her clothes and asks her to turn her back, but refuses out of respect.
Shows protective and considerate behavior by suggesting Ada and Ruby go ahead while he follows with the horse at a pace her father can tolerate.
Expresses heartfelt intention to marry Ada and shows patient willingness to wait.
Refuses to turn his back while Ada undresses, showing confidence and respect.
Plans the group's travel with safety in mind, suggesting Ruby goes ahead because it's safer and less likely to provoke conflict.
Gets close to Ada and speaks to her with a gentle, lighthearted tone, sharing a story and smiling.
Requests permission to live at Black Cove, showing respect to Ruby and the community.
Watches the two women depart silently, showing contemplative observation without intrusion.
Shoots wounded enemies to end their suffering after battle chaos.
Engages in violent combat, killing multiple opponents without apparent hesitation.
Attempts to persuade Bosie to disarm and leave peacefully, stating he is tired of fighting and will not shoot him.
Responds to Bosie's gunfire by killing him with a headshot.
Watches silently after killing Bosie and clears his throat with a thin mist of blood, showing a somber, reserved reaction to the violence.
Referred to by Ada warmly ('Grace Inman, nobody said eat') indicating familiarity and informal friendliness.
No direct actions in this excerpt; presence implied in a warm, communal setting with shared food and prayer, suggesting trust and inclusion.
